title: 111_hr135
content:
The "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2009" establishes a commission to address the increasing stress on the nation's water resources. The Commission's duties include assessing technological and economic advances to increase water supplies and developing a comprehensive strategy for sustainable water availability. The Commission established by the "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2009" is tasked with conducting water assessments, studying water management programs, and developing a comprehensive water strategy in consultation with relevant agencies and entities. The Commission aims to ensure a reliable water supply for the next 50 years, avoid burdening State and local governments, streamline Federal programs, optimize water supply technologies, capture excess water for conservation, and propose financing options for water management projects. The Commission aims to ensure a reliable water supply for the next 50 years by suggesting strategies to conserve existing water supplies, including repairing aging infrastructure, and other objectives related to effective water management. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment: 5 by the President, 2 by the Speaker of the House, and 2 by the Senate majority leader. Members must have expertise in water policy and cannot hold any other US government position while serving on the Commission. The Commission members, appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, represent diverse regional perspectives. The President designates the Chairperson, and members serve for the Commission's duration. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Commission members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment represent diverse regional perspectives. They serve without compensation but receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, as per applicable provisions. SEC. 6. MEETINGS AND QUORUM.

The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed and additional meetings as needed. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business.

SEC. 7. STAFFING.

The Chairperson can appoint an Executive Director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Executive Director's compensation should not exceed the annual rate of basic pay for GS-15. Confirmation by a majority of Commission members is required for the Executive Director's employment and termination. SEC. 8. POWERS AND PROCEEDINGS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall hold at least 10 hearings, including one in Washington, DC, and others in different regions of the US to gather diverse testimony on water issues. Federal agencies must provide requested information within 30 days. The Commission must provide necessary information within 30 days of request and assign personnel on temporary duty for the Act's provisions. SEC. 9. REPORTS. The Commission is required to submit interim reports every 6 months detailing its progress to the President and relevant congressional committees. A final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation must be submitted within 3 years of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission must submit findings and conclusions to the President and specific congressional committees. SEC. 10. TERMINATION. The Commission will end within 30 days of submitting the final report. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $9,000,000 is authorized for this Act.
